Description.val: This line item funds modifications to the EA-6B aircraft.  The EA-6B Prowler is a four-seat, twin-engine, mid-wing, tactical, electronic attack aircraft.  The EA-6B is flown by only Marine Corps squadrons in FY 2016 to provide DoD tactical electronic attack capability.   The projected inventory is 28 ICAP III aircraft in FY 2016, all in Active service.  Four (4) ICAP III aircraft will be in Section 1 Level 1000 preservation in FY 2016.  The designated service life is 12,500 flight hours, with an average of 3,750 flight hours of service life remaining per aircraft.   Modifications budgeted and programmed include software/hardware modifications for correction of deficiencies, mandates, and to address obsolescence issues.

Justification.val: The EA-6B Prowler is a Low Density High Demand electronic attack platform. The aircraft are 40+ years old. Considerable modifications have been required in two basic categories to keep the systems viable: weapons delivery and airframe reliability. Weapons delivery includes Airborne Electronic Attack (AEA) systems and its ancillary equipment. Several systems on the aircraft are based on obsolete software and techniques. Modifications are required to maintain safety of flight as the platform ages; Fatigue Life Expended (FLE), advanced corrosion, and tired iron must be addressed. These investments are required to keep the aircraft and its systems/subsystems viable until the platform is retired.

Name.@footnote: Other Support includes field activity and depot support required to manage modification efforts.

In FY14-16 OSIP 032-85 funds recurring costs related to Audio Intercommunication System AIC-45 and Fuel Flow Transmitter installation engineering on the EA-6B aircraft.  Center Wing Section (CWS) Harvest engineering and modernization kits are an emergant requirement.  The cost to modernize the CWS varies depends on condition.  Throughout this timeframe, the mix of kits being purchased causes a variation in the yearly unit cost on the Aircraft Systems, Aircraft Avionics, and Aircraft Structures.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Depot Field Mod Team:: Installation Name: Avionics / Aircraft Systems
DEPOT FIELD MOD TEAM:: Installation Name: AIRCRAFT STRUCTURES

Description.val:
This Operational and Safety Improvement Program covers EA-6B Structural, Systems, Sub-Systems, and Avionics modifications and improvement to mission degrading deficiencies discovered during test reviews, flight line inspections, and preventive maintenance inspections related to reliability, maintainability, sustainability, training, and safety of flight.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR MILESTONES:
Major milestones include the completion of the Digital Flight Control System test program and Wing Center Section production deliveries.

Current Modifications: 

Aircraft Systems (Systems/Sub-Systems Readiness Improvements) - Includes modifications to improve reliability and maintainability of avionics, electrical, life support, propulsion/power, landing gear, hydraulics, pneumatic, primary secondary flight controls, and environmental control systems.

Aircraft Avionics (Avionics Readiness Improvements) - Includes modifications to improve reliability and maintainability of avionics, software, components, wiring, weapons control, communication, navigation, radar, and display systems.

Aircraft Structures (Structural Readiness Improvements) - Includes required modifications based on fatigue life analysis and aircraft changes to ensure EA-6B aircraft availability, reliability, and maintainability of airframe structural components through FY19.

Funding provided to support all EA-6B airframe readiness, hardware readiness, electrical component readiness, obsolescence prevention, inspections, installations, and safety of flight improvements throughout remaining airframe service. Fund application to the structure, system/subsystem, and avionics deficiencies will be made to ensure aircraft service readiness and reliability.

Beginning in FY16, OSIP 032-85 will be budgeted under OSIP 01-01 ICAP III with the exception of installation costs for FY15 procurements.

Name.@footnote: Other Support includes field activity and depot support required to manage emergent aircraft safety modifications.
The cost growth within the Avionics cost element driven by the combination of software/hardware kits being purchased (MIDs, USB-ENTR, etc.)
Emergent Safety requirements line includes funds for aircraft modifications related to safety/national security interests mandatory for the aircraft to reach its full service life.

ImplementationMethodName.val: DEPOT FIELD MOD TEAM:: Installation Name:  AVIONICS

Description.val:
This Operational and Safety Improvement Program covers the EA-6B Improved Capabilities III (ICAP III) system modifications.  Specifically, the modification program replaced the ALQ-99 Receiver System with the ALQ-218 receiver system, replaced the TDY-43 display system with a new Commercial Off The Shelf (COTS) based display system for the Pilot and three Electronic Countermeasures Officers (ECMOs), upgraded the Recorder Reproducer Set with a new Digital Recorder, incorporated the Multi-Mission Advanced Tactical Terminal (MATT) to provide reception of data links, incorporated the USQ-113 Communication Receiver/Jammer with the ALQ-218, updated mission planning for ICAP III to Joint Mission Planning System (JMPS), and incorporated Link-16 to include basic electronic warfare battle management capabilities.  LITENING Pod integration provides a demonstrated capability and usefulness to support integrated targeting and convoy protection when using the AN/AAQ-28 LITENING Pod system on AV-8B aircraft in conjunction with EA-6B aircraft.

AVIONICS KITS: Software/hardware modifications for correction of deficiencies, mandates, and to address obsolescence issues associated with Multi-functional Information Distribution System (MIDs), MATT replacement (USB ENTR), Cryptographic mod kits, ARN-153 Tactical Air Navigational System, and AIC-45 Intercom.

MISSION PLANNING ENVIRONMENT (MPE): MPE requires framework integration modifications to avoid Microsoft Operating System (XP) obsolescence and out of cycle technology refresh of Mission Planning laptops in a Windows 7 environment. MPE software requires changes to ensure parity with aircraft OFP.  

AIRCRAFT SYSTEMS AND STRUCTURES (SYSTEMS/SUB-SYSTEMS SAFETY AND OBSOLESCENCE): Includes modifications to improve safety and address obsolescence issues of avionics, electrical, life support, propulsion/power, landing gear, hydraulics, pneumatic, primary secondary flight controls, and environmental control systems.
	
DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: Following a Full and Open Competition, Milestone II approval was received, and an Engineering and Manufacturing Development (EMD) Research Development Test & Evaluation development contract was awarded to the Northrop Grumman Corporation in March 1998. Following a Development Test/Operational Test period, completion of an Operational Assessment and an LRIP decision, a Low Rate Initial Production contract were awarded in FY03. Following completion of Operational Evaluation and a Milestone III decision, a full rate production contract was awarded in the 2nd quarter FY06. Additional Full Rate Production contracts designated for Lot 3 & Lot 4 were awarded in FY08.

Beginning in FY16, OSIP 032-85 funds have transitioned to OSIP 01-01 ICAP III with the exception of installation costs for FY15 procurements.
